background: Point-count monitoring is a common way to monitor bird populations with a relatively small amount of work compared to other methods. Itis a quantitative assessment, involving repeated measures at regular intervals at fixed locations to reveal change. It is characterized by tallying all birds observed at a fixed location during specific, timed, repeated observation periods. It provides the relative abundance of all bird species and, over time, can detect trends in abundance. This protocol uses a habitat-based approach to stratify points by vegetation type so bird abundance can be more closely aligned by community structure and/or composition.Such work can be very meaningful when pooled with a larger body of compatible data.
title: Breeding Bird Point Count Monitoring on the Precious Lands Wildlife Management Area
assumptions:
1) Personnel are adequately trained to identify all species in area by visual and auditory means.

2) A constant fraction of individuals present in an area is counted over the timescale and location of interest; i.e. detection probabilities remain consistent across time and space.

3) The total number of birds counted is consistently and linearly correlated with the actual density of the population.

4) Birds are not knowingly double-counted in any one count period at a count station.

5) The population remains demographically closed throughout the survey period.
objectives: Develop habitat management guidelines to maintain, restore, and enhance bird populations.
Identify how management activities influence distribution and abundance of species.
Examine relationship between habitat characteristics and species abundance patterns.
Identify bird species and populations that are increasing, decreasing, or stable.
